content.body: For any two positive integers a and b, there exist unique integers q and r such that a = bq + r, where 0 ≤ r < b. Here a is the dividend, b is the divisor, q is the quotient, and r is the remainder. Used to find HCF.
content.analogy: Like dividing 17 apples equally among 5 people — each gets 3 (q) with 2 left over (r): 17 = 5×3 + 2.

content.body: For any two positive integers a and b: HCF(a,b) × LCM(a,b) = a × b. This relationship helps find one when the other is known. HCF divides both numbers; LCM is divisible by both.
content.analogy: HCF is the greatest factor they share (what they have in common); LCM is the smallest multiple they share (where they meet again).

content.exactPhrase: To prove a number irrational, assume it is rational, write it as p/q in lowest terms (HCF of p and q = 1), then derive a contradiction showing both p and q are divisible by the same number.
content.instruction: Always state 'Assume √2 = p/q where p and q are integers and HCF(p,q) = 1' at the start. Then square both sides and derive the contradiction — this is the standard proof structure examiners expect.

content.question: What is the HCF of 12 and 18?
content.explanation: 12 = 2² × 3 and 18 = 2 × 3². HCF = product of smallest powers of common factors = 2¹ × 3¹ = 6. Alternatively, factors of 12: 1,2,3,4,6,12; factors of 18: 1,2,3,6,9,18; highest common = 6.

content.story: Remember the formula a = bq + r as 'Always Bring Quick Results': A = B × Q + R. Constraints: 0 ≤ r < b. The remainder r is always less than the divisor b and can never be negative. Think of dividing a pie — leftover crumbs (r) must be fewer than a full slice (b).

content.body: Standard form: ax² + bx + c = 0 where a ≠ 0. Three methods: (1) Factorisation — split middle term. (2) Completing the square — add and subtract (b/2a)². (3) Quadratic formula: x = (-b ± √(b²-4ac)) / 2a. The formula always works when factorisation fails.
content.analogy: A quadratic is a parabola — its roots are where it crosses the x-axis. No real roots means it doesn't touch the ground.

content.body: The discriminant D = b² - 4ac determines the nature of roots: D > 0 gives two distinct real roots, D = 0 gives two equal (repeated) real roots, D < 0 means no real roots (imaginary). Calculate D before attempting to solve.
content.analogy: D is like a weather forecast for your equation: positive means two solutions ahead, zero means one, negative means no real solution today.

content.exactPhrase: If D > 0: two distinct real roots. If D = 0: two equal real roots. If D < 0: no real roots (roots are not real).
content.instruction: Always compute D = b² - 4ac first and state its value in the solution. For 'find the nature of roots' questions, this single calculation earns marks even without solving the full equation.

content.question: What is the discriminant of x² − 5x + 6 = 0?
content.explanation: a = 1, b = −5, c = 6. D = b² − 4ac = (−5)² − 4(1)(6) = 25 − 24 = 1. Since D = 1 > 0, the equation has two distinct real roots (x = 2 and x = 3).

content.story: D > 0: Two roads ahead (two distinct roots). D = 0: Equal twins on the path (two equal roots). D < 0: No real friends today (no real roots). Story: A traveller (equation) checks the discriminant forecast before crossing. Positive? Two crossings. Zero? One spot. Negative? Stay home — no real crossing!

content.body: An AP is a sequence where each term differs from the previous by a constant called the common difference (d). First term: a. nth term: aₙ = a + (n−1)d. To check if a sequence is AP, verify that consecutive differences are equal.
content.analogy: Like climbing stairs where each step is the same height — each step is d, and the height after n steps is a + (n−1)d.

subject: Math
topic: Sum of n Terms of AP

content.topic: Sum of n Terms of AP
content.body: Sₙ = n/2 × [2a + (n−1)d] or equivalently Sₙ = n/2 × (first term + last term). The first form is used when first term and common difference are known; the second when first and last terms are known.
content.analogy: Gauss added 1+2+...+100 by pairing first and last (1+100, 2+99...) — 50 pairs each summing 101. That's the same idea: average × count.

content.exactPhrase: If three numbers are in AP, take them as a−d, a, a+d. Their sum equals 3a.
content.instruction: Always use this substitution when a question gives the sum of three terms in AP. Similarly for four terms in AP: a−3d, a−d, a+d, a+3d. This simplifies calculations dramatically — examiners expect this shortcut.

content.question: What is the 7th term of the AP: 2, 5, 8, 11, ...?

content.story: An AP is like climbing stairs where every step has the same height (d). You start at height a. After climbing n steps, you're at height a + (n−1)d. The sum formula counts total height climbed across all steps. Visualise each term as a stair — equal spacing, perfect pattern.

content.body: If a line is drawn parallel to one side of a triangle, it divides the other two sides in the same ratio. That is, if DE ∥ BC in triangle ABC, then AD/DB = AE/EC. The converse is also true — if a line divides two sides in equal ratio, it is parallel to the third.
content.analogy: Like a shadow — a parallel light beam cutting through a triangle creates proportional segments, just as a horizontal floor cut creates scaled copies.

content.body: Three criteria: AA (Angle-Angle) — two equal angles. SSS (Side-Side-Side) — all three sides in proportion. SAS (Side-Angle-Side) — two sides in proportion with included angle equal. Similarity means same shape, different size — all corresponding angles equal, all sides in the same ratio.
content.analogy: A photograph and its enlargement are similar — same shape, different size. The ratio of enlargement is constant for all sides.

content.exactPhrase: The ratio of the areas of two similar triangles is equal to the square of the ratio of their corresponding sides.
content.instruction: Write this theorem before area ratio problems. If sides are in ratio k:1, then areas are in ratio k²:1. E.g., sides 2:3 → areas 4:9. This is frequently asked in board exams — state the theorem, then apply it.

content.question: Two similar triangles have corresponding sides in ratio 2:3. What is the ratio of their areas?
content.explanation: Area ratio = (side ratio)² = (2/3)² = 4/9. So the areas are in ratio 4:9. Remember: for similar triangles, area ratio = square of side ratio, not the side ratio itself.

content.story: Similar triangles are like a photo and its enlargement — same shape, different sizes (sides proportional, angles equal). Congruent triangles are like two identical photocopies — exact same shape AND size. Remember: Similar = Scaled, Congruent = Carbon Copy.

content.body: The distance between two points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is: d = √[(x₂−x₁)² + (y₂−y₁)²]. This is derived from the Pythagorean theorem applied to the right triangle formed by the horizontal and vertical distances between the points.
content.analogy: Like finding the length of the diagonal of a rectangle whose width is the horizontal gap and height is the vertical gap.

content.body: A point P dividing the line segment joining A(x₁,y₁) and B(x₂,y₂) in ratio m:n (internally) has coordinates: x = (mx₂ + nx₁)/(m+n), y = (my₂ + ny₁)/(m+n). For midpoint, m = n = 1, giving M = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2).
content.analogy: Like splitting a journey in ratio m:n — if you've covered m/(m+n) of the total distance, your current position is weighted accordingly.

content.exactPhrase: Midpoint of a line segment with endpoints (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is M = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2).
content.instruction: Use this formula whenever asked to find the centre of a segment, the centroid of a triangle (average of all three vertices), or to verify if a point bisects a line. Always show each coordinate calculation separately to earn step marks.

content.question: What is the distance between the points (0, 0) and (3, 4)?
content.explanation: d = √[(3−0)² + (4−0)²] = √[9 + 16] = √25 = 5. This is a classic 3-4-5 right triangle. Always check if a Pythagorean triplet applies before doing full calculation.

content.story: Draw a right triangle between your two points — horizontal leg = (x₂−x₁), vertical leg = (y₂−y₁), hypotenuse = distance. So d² = (Δx)² + (Δy)². Pythagoras from Class 9 is still working for you! Common triplets: 3-4-5, 5-12-13, 8-15-17.
